feature: Sample 1 (index 0) - Early upward peak (peak): occurrence ~t=18-26; amplitude ~+2.3 to +2.8 above baseline y=0; morphology: narrow, sharp rise and fall (single localized bump). Time-frequency: concentrated high energy at very low frequency rows (0 Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows) during t≈18-26. Heatmap mapping: strong red at the 0Hz / adjacent low-frequency rows in the same time window. Interpretation: typical feature (red) – the model treats this early upward peak as a characteristic signature for label 0.

Sample 1 (index 0) - Mid long downward trough (valley): occurrence ~t=44-88; amplitude around -1.7 to -2.1 (sustained negative plateau below y=0); morphology: extended flat trough with smooth edges (long-duration valley). Time-frequency: strong low-frequency energy across t≈45-85 concentrated at the 0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows. Heatmap mapping: dominant red at 0Hz rows/time window covering the trough (some minor faint cold tones in higher rows but red dominant). Interpretation: typical feature (red) – the sustained downward trough is considered a prototypical cue for label 0.

Sample 1 (index 0) - Late return to baseline / small jitter (baseline/other): occurrence ~t=92-149; amplitude close to 0 with low-amplitude jitter ~±0.1; morphology: near-flat baseline with small noise. Time-frequency: very low energy across frequencies in late window. Heatmap mapping: near-neutral to faint red at low frequency (weak contribution). Interpretation: weak/neutral to mildly typical (mostly not decisive for classification).

Sample 2 (index 3) - Early-to-mid downward trough (valley): occurrence ~t=50-95; amplitude about -1.7 to -2.1 (sustained valley). Morphology: fast descent from near-zero to sustained trough, then sharp recovery. Time-frequency: concentrated low-frequency energy (0Hz and adjacent rows) spanning the trough interval. Heatmap mapping: strong red over the 0Hz low-frequency rows at the trough times. Interpretation: typical feature (red) – model strongly relies on this trough as label indicator.

Sample 2 (index 3) - Late sharp upward peak (peak): occurrence ~t=120-128; amplitude ~+2.0 to +2.2; morphology: abrupt rise then decay (narrow spike at late time). Time-frequency: localized high-energy low-frequency content around the spike time. Heatmap mapping: red emphasis at low-frequency rows in the late window. Interpretation: typical feature (red) – the late upward spike is considered characteristic of the label in this sample.

Sample 2 (index 3) - Early baseline jitter (baseline): occurrence ~t=0-45; amplitude around 0 to +0.1; morphology: small noise-like oscillations. Time-frequency: minimal energy. Heatmap mapping: near-zero contribution (no strong color). Interpretation: neutral/irrelevant to classification.

Sample 3 (index 6) - Small early upward pulse (peak): occurrence ~t=18-26; amplitude ~+2.0 (narrow spike); morphology: single sharp bump. Time-frequency: localized low-frequency energy at that early time. Heatmap mapping: red at 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows at the early pulse. Interpretation: typical (red) – model treats the early isolated peak as positively indicative.

Sample 3 (index 6) - Large sustained elevated plateau (other / peak-like plateau): occurrence ~t=50-106; amplitude ~+2.05 to +2.2 (long-duration elevated signal, flat-top plateau). Morphology: long high-level plateau (sustained high amplitude), followed by return to baseline. Time-frequency: strong energy concentrated in the 0Hz row and adjacent very-low-frequency rows across the plateau window; some spread to slightly higher low-frequency rows indicating a broad energy footprint. Heatmap mapping: mixed coloring: some low-frequency cells marked red but a significant contiguous area in the core low-frequency rows/time window is blue (negative SHAP) while adjacent rows/times show red. Interpretation: ambiguous / mixed — parts of the plateau (certain frequency components/time slices) are treated as typical (red) while others (notably core 0Hz cells across part of the plateau) are treated as atypical (blue). The overall plateau is therefore not uniformly typical; the model is partially confused or regards some components as atypical.

Sample 3 (index 6) - Abrupt drop at plateau end (other): occurrence ~t≈108-115; amplitude steep fall from ~+2.1 to ~0; morphology: sharp descent. Time-frequency: transient energy at low-frequency rows during descent. Heatmap mapping: weak mixed coloring (slight red/neutral). Interpretation: mildly typical/neutral.

Sample 4 (index 9) - Long early plateau (other / plateau): occurrence ~t=54-105; amplitude ~+2.05 to +2.17 (extended high plateau). Morphology: rapid rise into sustained high plateau, then strong descent. Time-frequency: concentrated low-frequency energy on 0Hz and adjacent rows across t≈54-105. Heatmap mapping: dominant blue at the core 0Hz low-frequency rows in the plateau time window while some adjacent frequency rows/times show neutral or small red. Interpretation: atypical feature (blue) — the model considers the early sustained plateau to be atypical for label 0 (i.e., resembles other labels or contradicts expected patterns).

Sample 4 (index 9) - Later isolated peak (peak): occurrence ~t=120-128; amplitude ~+2.1 to +2.2 (short spike). Morphology: isolated sharp rise and return. Time-frequency: concentrated low-frequency energy at the later time. Heatmap mapping: strong red at low-frequency rows in the later spike window. Interpretation: typical feature (red) — the late isolated peak is a positive signature for label 0 in this sample.

Sample 4 (index 9) - Early baseline / low jitter (baseline): occurrence ~t=0-52; amplitude ~0 to +0.1; morphology: low-level noise. Time-frequency: very low energy. Heatmap mapping: neutral to faint colors. Interpretation: neutral/irrelevant.

valley - Mid sustained downward trough: occurrence t≈54–96; amplitude ≈ -1.7 to -1.9 below baseline; morphology: long-duration, flat-bottom trough with smooth edges (sustained negative plateau). Time-frequency: strong, concentrated energy in the 0Hz row and adjacent very-low-frequency rows across the trough interval. Heatmap marking: dominated by red in the 0Hz/adjacent low-frequency rows for this time window (treated as a typical feature). Note: the preliminary summary described a large sustained elevated (positive) plateau with mixed/ambiguous heatmap colors for index 6; in the current sample this event is a negative trough and is marked as a typical (red) feature by the model.

other - Sharp recovery (abrupt rise) from trough to baseline: occurrence t≈96–104; morphology: steep positive slope rising from the sustained trough (~-1.8) back to ~0 over a few time steps (transient). Time-frequency: transient low-frequency energy at the recovery time. Heatmap marking: neutral to slightly red at the low-frequency rows (weakly typical/neutral).

baseline - Late near-baseline small jitter: occurrence t≈105–149; amplitude close to 0 with small low-amplitude noise (~±0.1). Time-frequency: very low energy across frequencies. Heatmap marking: neutral to very faint red in low-frequency rows (weak/irrelevant to classification).

peak - Early narrow upward spike: occurrence t ≈ 18–26; amplitude ≈ +1.2 to +1.4 above baseline; morphology: short, sharp isolated bump (single localized spike). Time-frequency: concentrated energy in the 0 Hz row and adjacent very-low-frequency rows during the spike window. Heatmap marking: red in low-frequency rows at the spike time. Interpretation: typical feature (red) — the model treats this early spike as a positive cue. (Note: preliminary summary for index 9 described a later isolated peak; it did not record an early narrow spike at t≈18–26 in this sample.)

valley - Mid sustained deep downward trough: occurrence t ≈ 44–82; amplitude ≈ -2.1 to -2.3 (deeper than the -1.7 to -1.9 ranges previously summarized); morphology: long-duration flat-bottom trough (sustained negative plateau) with smooth ingress/egress. Time-frequency: strong, concentrated energy in the 0 Hz row and adjacent very-low-frequency rows across the trough interval. Heatmap marking: predominantly red in low-frequency rows for much of the trough (typical), but with localized blue markings in core 0 Hz cells/time-slices (particularly in the earlier portion of the trough window), producing a mixed red/blue pattern across frequency components and across the trough duration. Interpretation: mainly typical (red) for label 0 but with partial atypical components (blue) — the model is partly confused for certain frequency components/time-slices of the trough.

other - Rapid recovery (steep rise) from trough to baseline: occurrence t ≈ 82–92; morphology: sharp steep slope returning from ~-2.2 back to ~0 over ~10 time steps (transient). Time-frequency: transient low-frequency energy at recovery time. Heatmap marking: neutral to slightly red in low-frequency rows. Interpretation: mildly typical/weakly supporting (not a strong decisive cue).

baseline - Late near-baseline small jitter: occurrence t ≈ 94–149; amplitude ≈ 0 ± 0.1; morphology: near-flat baseline with low-amplitude noise. Time-frequency: very low energy across frequencies in late window. Heatmap marking: neutral to very faint red in the low-frequency rows. Interpretation: weak/irrelevant to classification.
pattern: Pattern for Sample 1 (index 0): Early narrow upward peak at t≈18-26 (peak, +2.3–+2.8) (red at 0Hz/adjacent low frequencies) typical + Mid extended downward trough at t≈44-88 (valley, -1.7 to -2.1) (red concentrated on 0Hz/low-frequency rows) typical + Late near-baseline stability t≈92-149 (baseline jitter, neutral). Interpretation: a two-event pattern (early peak + long trough) where both main deviations are strong low-frequency events that the model regards as typical cues for label 0.

Pattern for Sample 2 (index 3): Mid sustained trough t≈50-95 (valley, -1.7 to -2.1) (red @0Hz low-frequency) typical + Late sharp isolated upward peak t≈120-128 (peak, +2.0–+2.2) (red @0Hz) typical + Early near-zero jitter t≈0-45 neutral. Interpretation: a trough-dominated sample with a late compensatory peak; both large deviations are considered typical by the model.

Pattern for Sample 3 (index 6): Early narrow upward pulse t≈18-26 (peak, +2.0) (red at low-frequency) typical + Long sustained plateau t≈50-106 (other/plateau, +2.05–+2.2) with mixed heatmap colors: core low-frequency cells during much of the plateau show blue (atypical) while some adjacent low-frequency components/time slices show red (typical). Overall the plateau is ambiguous/mixed (partial atypical signature) + End abrupt drop t≈108-115 (neutral). Interpretation: combined pattern where the sample contains both a clearly typical early peak and a large plateau whose frequency decomposition confuses the model (some components push classification away, others toward it).

Pattern for Sample 4 (index 9): Early long plateau t≈54-105 (plateau, +2.05–+2.17) with dominant blue at the 0Hz low-frequency rows (atypical) + Later isolated peak t≈120-128 (peak, +2.1–+2.2) (red at 0Hz) typical + Early baseline noise t≈0-52 neutral. Interpretation: a two-phase sample where the early sustained high plateau is regarded as atypical by the model while a later isolated spike is treated as a prototypical positive cue for the label. The model thus differentiates between sustained high-level energy and short localized spikes by treating them with opposite importance signs in the heatmap.

Early narrow upward peak at t≈18–26 (peak, +~1.8 to +1.9) (red @0Hz/adjacent low-frequency rows) (typical) + Mid sustained downward trough t≈54–96 (valley, -~1.7 to -~1.9) (strong red @0Hz/adjacent low-frequency rows) (typical) + Rapid recovery t≈96–104 (steep rise to baseline) (neutral/slightly red) + Late near-baseline small jitter t≈105–149 (neutral). Explanation: the model treats both the early isolated positive spike and the long middle negative trough as prototypical low-frequency cues (red) for this sample; the recovery is a short transient with weak contribution and the late baseline jitter is essentially neutral.

Early narrow positive spike t ≈ 18–26 (peak, +1.2–+1.4) (red @ 0 Hz & adjacent low-frequency rows) (typical) + Mid long sustained deep negative trough t ≈ 44–82 (valley, -2.1 to -2.3) (strong energy @ 0 Hz & adjacent low-frequency rows) (predominantly red but with localized blue in core 0 Hz cells/time-slices → mixed/partially atypical) + Rapid recovery t ≈ 82–92 (steep rise to baseline) (neutral/slightly red) + Late near-baseline small jitter t ≈ 94–149 (neutral). Explanation: the sample's decisive structure is an early short positive spike followed by a dominant mid negative plateau. The trough is mostly treated by the model as a typical label-0 cue (red in low frequencies) but contains frequency/time components that the model flags as atypical (blue), indicating partial confusion about some frequency components of the sustained trough. The preliminary summary did not explicitly document the early narrow spike at t≈18–26 for this sample nor the deeper trough amplitude (~-2.1 to -2.3) and the within-trough mixed red/blue frequency-component marking — these are the missing pattern details supplied here.

feature: Sample 12 (label 1) - Baseline (early 0-45 & late 105-149): type=baseline; manifestation=near-zero level with small random jitter/noise, values clustered around 0.0 to ~0.08 (normalized), morphology=flat low-amplitude fluctuations; STFT mapping=very low energy across all frequency rows outside the middle window; heatmap mapping=mostly neutral to light-red/very small positive SHAP values in peripheral low-frequency rows; interpretation=typical (model treats quiet baseline as normal background, though contribution is small).

Sample 12 (label 1) - Rising transition (approx. 45-54): type=other (trend change); manifestation=sharp upward ramp from ~0 to ~2.1 over ~6-10 time steps (high rate of change); STFT mapping=appearance of concentrated low-frequency (0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows) high energy during the ramp; heatmap mapping=red concentrated in 0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows in this time window; interpretation=typical feature (transition energy at low frequencies strongly supports label 1).

Sample 12 (label 1) - Middle plateau (approx. 54-95): type=peak/plateau; manifestation=wide, stable high plateau with amplitude approx. 2.05–2.25 (very low internal volatility), morphology=flat-top plateau rather than isolated sharp peak; STFT mapping=strong energy concentrated at the 0Hz row and immediately adjacent low-frequency rows (dominant low-frequency band); heatmap mapping=strong red across the 0Hz row and neighboring low-frequency rows during the plateau time window; interpretation=typical feature (core discriminative region).

Sample 12 (label 1) - Falling transition (approx. 95-105): type=other (trend change); manifestation=rapid decrease from plateau back to baseline over ~6-12 time steps, similar slope magnitude to rising transition; STFT mapping=low-frequency energy concentrated in same low-frequency components as the rising transition; heatmap mapping=red emphasis on low-frequency rows at the descent; interpretation=typical feature (transition energy contributes positively to class).

Sample 13 (label 1) - Baseline (early/late): type=baseline; manifestation=near-zero small jitter amplitude ~0.0–0.1 before and after plateau; STFT mapping=negligible energy; heatmap mapping=mostly neutral to faint red in low-freq rows; interpretation=typical/neutral background.

Sample 13 (label 1) - Rising transition (approx. 48-55): type=other (trend change); manifestation=steep rise to plateau, rate similar to Sample 12; STFT mapping=low-frequency band activation concentrated at 0Hz and adjacent rows; heatmap mapping=red dominant in 0Hz row and adjacent rows across rising interval; interpretation=typical.

Sample 13 (label 1) - Middle plateau (approx. 55-100): type=plateau; manifestation=stable high amplitude ~2.0–2.2 with tiny local wiggles only, morphology=flat and long; STFT mapping=very strong energy at 0Hz row and immediate neighboring low-frequency rows, little high-frequency spread; heatmap mapping=strong red concentrated on low-frequency rows during plateau; interpretation=typical feature.

Sample 13 (label 1) - Falling transition (approx. 100-108): type=other; manifestation=rapid descent to baseline, symmetric to rise; STFT mapping=low-frequency energy; heatmap mapping=red in low-frequency rows; interpretation=typical.

Sample 18 (label 1) - Baseline (early 0-45 & late 100-149): type=baseline; manifestation=early baseline shows slightly larger jitter compared to other samples (values up to ~0.2 in some points), morphology=more visible random fluctuations; STFT mapping=some elevated energy in slightly higher low-frequency rows during baseline (pre-plateau); heatmap mapping=light red in lower rows but notable small blue markings present at intermediate frequency rows (0.1–0.2 region) in some time windows; interpretation=baseline mostly typical but contains slight atypical higher-frequency content (mixed).

Sample 18 (label 1) - Rising transition (approx. 45-54): type=other; manifestation=fast rise to plateau (similar amplitude ~2.1–2.3), STFT mapping=strong low-frequency activation plus some spread to slightly higher frequency rows indicating mild jitter or transient energy; heatmap mapping=red concentrated at 0Hz row for transition but also patches of blue in adjacent intermediate rows; interpretation=mixed: core low-frequency transition is typical (red) while higher-frequency components during the transition are atypical (blue) indicating model confusion about those components.

Sample 18 (label 1) - Middle plateau (approx. 54-95): type=plateau; manifestation=stable high amplitude ~2.1–2.3 with small internal jitter; STFT mapping=dominant energy in 0Hz row but with more energy in adjacent low-to-intermediate frequencies than other samples; heatmap mapping=red concentrated in 0Hz row (typical) but also several blue spots at intermediate frequency rows (0.08–0.25 region) during the plateau and transitions; interpretation=mixed: the stationary low-frequency plateau is a typical discriminative feature, while additional intermediate-frequency energy (jitter) is treated as atypical by the model.

Sample 18 (label 1) - Falling transition (approx. 95-105): type=other; manifestation=drop from plateau to baseline with asymmetric small oscillation mid-descent; STFT mapping=low-frequency energy with some spread to intermediate rows; heatmap mapping=combination of red at 0Hz and blue at some intermediate frequencies; interpretation=ambiguous/mixed contribution.

Sample 21 (label 1) - Baseline (early/late): type=baseline; manifestation=very low-level jitter similar to Samples 12/13 (~0.0–0.09), morphology=flat; STFT mapping=low energy; heatmap mapping=almost no colored contributions except faint red in mid-window low-freq rows; interpretation=typical/neutral background.

Sample 21 (label 1) - Rising transition (approx. 45-54): type=other; manifestation=fast ramp to plateau, STFT mapping=clear low-frequency activation (0Hz & adjacent rows); heatmap mapping=red concentrated in 0Hz row during rising window; interpretation=typical feature.

Sample 21 (label 1) - Middle plateau (approx. 54-95): type=plateau; manifestation=long stable plateau amplitude ~2.05–2.2 with minimal jitter; STFT mapping=very concentrated energy on 0Hz row with adjacent low-frequency rows contributing; heatmap mapping=strong red across 0Hz row and low-frequency neighbors in plateau time window; interpretation=strongly typical feature (core positive evidence for label 1).

Sample 21 (label 1) - Falling transition (approx. 95-105): type=other; manifestation=faster descent to baseline, STFT mapping=low-frequency energy; heatmap mapping=red in 0Hz and low-frequency rows; interpretation=typical.
pattern: Sample 12 pattern: Baseline (0-45) low-noise (~0.0–0.08) (neutral/light-red) + Rising transition (45-54) sharp upward ramp to plateau (0→~2.1) (strong red on 0Hz & adjacent low-frequency rows => typical) + Middle plateau (54-95) long stable high amplitude (~2.05–2.25) (very strong red concentrated at 0Hz row => core typical) + Falling transition (95-105) sharp descent to baseline (red low-frequency contribution => typical) + Late baseline (105-149) low-noise (neutral). Overall model relies on mid-window low-frequency energy as typical signature.

Sample 13 pattern: Baseline (0-48) quiet (neutral) + Rising transition (48-55) steep ramp (red at 0Hz low-freq rows => typical) + Middle plateau (55-100) stable high plateau (~2.0–2.2) (dominant red at 0Hz => typical) + Falling transition (100-108) descent (red => typical) + Late baseline (108-149) quiet. Pattern is almost identical to Sample 12 with red low-frequency energy dominating the discriminative evidence.

Sample 18 pattern: Baseline (0-45) slightly elevated jitter (~0.05–0.2) (mostly neutral/weak red but some intermediate-frequency energy present) + Rising transition (45-54) ramp to plateau (0→~2.2) (core low-frequency red, but STFT shows spread to intermediate frequencies and heatmap shows blue patches in those higher rows => mixed) + Middle plateau (54-95) stable high amplitude (~2.1–2.3) with more internal jitter (dominant red at 0Hz row but additional intermediate-frequency rows are blue => core typical plateau contaminated by atypical higher-frequency content) + Falling transition (95-105) descent (mixed red/blue) + Late baseline (105-149) small jitter. Pattern summary: central plateau + transitions are typical at 0Hz (red) but presence of intermediate/higher-frequency energy (blue) marks atypical components that reduce confidence/introduce ambiguity.

Sample 21 pattern: Baseline (0-45) quiet (neutral) + Rising transition (45-54) sharp ramp to plateau (0→~2.1) (red at 0Hz & adjacent rows => typical) + Middle plateau (54-95) long stable high amplitude (~2.05–2.2) (strong, concentrated red at 0Hz row => most typical representation) + Falling transition (95-105) sharp descent (red => typical) + Late baseline (105-149) quiet. Pattern highly prototypical for label 1: clear mid-segment plateau with concentrated low-frequency energy is the dominant positive evidence.

feature: Sample 24 (sample1): Early small valley (time ~13-22): morphology = sharp downward trough with minimum about -1.5 to -1.7 relative to y=0, duration short (≈6-12 time steps). Time-frequency: concentrated low-frequency energy in the 0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows during the same window. Heatmap color mapping: predominantly red on the 0Hz row and immediate low-frequency rows with a few faint blue pixels in some higher low-frequency rows. Interpretation: typical feature (red-dominated) at the 0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency components; slight ambiguous/atypical contributions at higher low-frequency bands (small blue spots) indicating minor frequency components that are not strongly typical.

Sample 24 (sample1): Middle long deep trough / plateau (time ~50-105): morphology = broad, sustained valley with amplitude about -2.0 to -2.2 (stable negative baseline across many time steps), very low volatility within the trough (flat bottom). Time-frequency: very strong energy concentrated at the 0Hz row and strongest adjacent low-frequency rows, weaker energy spilling into slightly higher frequency rows. Heatmap color mapping: dominant red across 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows for the whole trough window indicating a strong typical feature for label 2; there are isolated small blue pixels at some mid-low frequency rows in the later portion (~80-100) suggesting a few atypical frequency contributions, but red dominates so overall typical.

Sample 24 (sample1): Baseline small jitters (early and late, time ~0-13 and ~110-149): morphology = near-zero small oscillations around y=0, low amplitude. Time-frequency: very low energy across all frequency rows. Heatmap: mostly neutral/very light red or white (insignificant), thus not contributing meaningfully to classification (neither strongly typical nor atypical).

Sample 28 (sample2): Large central trough (time ~52-85): morphology = deep valley reaching about -2.2 to -2.4, sustained over many time steps with a flat bottom and sharp descent/ascent edges. Time-frequency: concentrated low-frequency energy (0Hz row strongest) during the trough. Heatmap: strong red across 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows across the trough window — interpreted as a typical feature (red-dominated) for label 2.

Sample 28 (sample2): Late smaller trough (time ~122-136): morphology = narrower but deep valley amplitude ~-2.0 to -2.15, shorter duration than central trough but pronounced. Time-frequency: low-frequency energy concentrated again in 0Hz row with some adjacent rows. Heatmap: strongly red on low-frequency rows for this late trough — typical feature. There are minor blue/neutral pixels in intermediate frequency rows across the series (indistinct) but do not dominate the trough region.

Sample 28 (sample2): Mid/late near-zero plateau (time ~95-115): morphology = near-zero to small positive jitter, low amplitude. Time-frequency: low energy. Heatmap: weak signals (light reds/whites) — not decisive.

Sample 30 (sample3): Early very deep sharp trough (time ~12-22): morphology = very deep negative valley (amplitude around -3.0 to -3.4), sharp descent and ascent (shorter duration than broad troughs), high magnitude deviation from y=0. Time-frequency: very strong energy concentrated at 0Hz and first few adjacent low-frequency rows; little high-frequency spread (relatively clean trough). Heatmap: clearly red at the 0Hz row and low-frequency band — strongly typical feature for label 2.

Sample 30 (sample3): Middle prolonged positive plateau (time ~50-95): morphology = sustained positive baseline around +1.1 to +1.5, low volatility across the window (flat-top). Time-frequency: energy present at low-frequency rows (0Hz and adjacent) corresponding to the stable plateau. Heatmap: red markings across the plateau window at low-frequency rows (typical) — the model treats this positive plateau in this sample as supporting evidence (red) for the sample's label context (despite label 2 generally defined by downward troughs, this plateau is treated by the model as a contributory typical pattern in this sample).

Sample 30 (sample3): Late small near-zero jitter (time ~100-149): morphology = small amplitude oscillations close to y=0. Time-frequency: negligible energy. Heatmap: neutral/very light color, not significant.

Sample 34 (sample4): Middle strong positive plateau (time ~50-105): morphology = sustained positive high baseline around +1.8 to +2.0, low volatility (flat plateau). Time-frequency: strong low-frequency energy concentrated at the 0Hz row and adjacent rows for the plateau window. Heatmap: notable blue (negative SHAP) at the 0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows during much of this plateau window (blue-dominated) — interpreted as atypical feature for label 2 (the model treats this mid positive plateau as evidence against the canonical label 2 pattern). A few adjacent higher low-frequency rows show weak red or neutral, creating some local ambiguity in upper components, but overall blue dominates the plateau window.

Sample 34 (sample4): Late deep trough (time ~122-132): morphology = distinct narrow negative trough reaching about -2.0 to -2.15, sharper descent/ascent. Time-frequency: low-frequency energy concentrated at 0Hz and immediate low-frequency rows. Heatmap: predominantly red at low-frequency rows during this trough — typical feature for label 2 (red-dominated).

Sample 34 (sample4): Early/late small baseline jitter (time outside main events): morphology = small oscillations near zero. Time-frequency: minimal. Heatmap: neutral/light colors — not classification-critical.
pattern: Pattern of Sample 24: Early short sharp valley (t≈13-22) (amplitude ≈ -1.5 to -1.7) (low-frequency 0Hz & adjacent rows red) (typical) + Middle long sustained deep trough/plateau (t≈50-105) (amplitude ≈ -2.0 to -2.2; flat-bottom, low volatility) (strong low-frequency 0Hz & adjacent rows red, with scattered small blue pixels at slightly higher low-frequency rows) (overall typical with minor atypical frequency contributions) + Peripheral near-zero jitter (t≲13 and t≳110) (negligible energy) (neutral).

Pattern of Sample 28: Central broad deep trough (t≈52-85) (amplitude ≈ -2.2 to -2.4; flat-bottom) (dominant low-frequency energy at 0Hz row red) (typical) + Late narrower deep trough (t≈122-136) (amplitude ≈ -2.0 to -2.15) (low-frequency red) (typical) + Intervening near-zero region (t≈95-115) (low energy) (neutral). Both troughs map to red-dominant low-frequency SHAP regions and are treated as prototypical label-2 features by the model.

Pattern of Sample 30: Early very deep narrow trough (t≈12-22) (amplitude ≈ -3.0 to -3.4; sharp) (very strong 0Hz low-frequency energy red) (typical) + Mid prolonged positive plateau (t≈50-95) (amplitude ≈ +1.1 to +1.5; flat-top, low volatility) (low-frequency red) (the model marks this plateau as a positive contributing feature for this sample — typical in the model's internal mapping even though plateau is positive) + End near-zero jitter (neutral). The combination shows the model relies strongly on the early deep trough and also treats the mid positive plateau as positively contributing to classification in this instance (red-dominant low-frequency contribution).

Pattern of Sample 34: Mid sustained positive plateau (t≈50-105) (amplitude ≈ +1.8 to +2.0; flat, low volatility) (low-frequency energy at 0Hz, but heatmap shows blue-dominated 0Hz rows during plateau) (atypical) + Late distinct negative trough (t≈122-132) (amplitude ≈ -2.0 to -2.15) (low-frequency rows red) (typical). In this sample the model considers the mid positive plateau to be evidence against canonical label-2 characteristics (blue-dominated low-frequency SHAP), while the later negative trough is a prototypical red-marked feature supporting the label.

Cross-sample frequency mapping note (emergent pattern across the four samples): Most classification-relevant events (both troughs and plateaus) concentrate their energy on the 0Hz row and immediate adjacent low-frequency rows (these rows capture the sustained baseline shifts and deep valleys). Where heatmaps are red in those rows that time window is treated as a typical feature for label 2; when the same low-frequency rows are blue in a time window (as in Sample 34's mid plateau) the model treats that time-frequency signature as atypical for label 2. Mixed red/blue patterns within the same time window (observed in a few mid-to-late portions of Sample 24) indicate local ambiguous features where some frequency components support the label while others push the prediction away.

feature: Large sustained mid-sequence plateau (occurrence ~t=50 to t=105): manifestation = high amplitude plateau (approx. 2.0–2.2 units), long duration (many consecutive time steps), morphology = flat / slowly varying top; time-frequency = very strong energy concentrated at the lowest frequency row (0Hz) and immediate adjacent low-frequency rows; heatmap color = strongly red at low-frequency rows (positive SHAP) with small mixed signs in adjacent rows. Interpretation = atypical for label-0 (which expects only a small early/final upward peak) and is a typical feature for class-1 in the black-box model; therefore this feature strongly drives misclassification (marked as typical for predicted class 1).

Absence of an isolated small early/final upward peak (occurrence expected near start or end but missing): manifestation = baseline-level noise or only small jitters around y=0 (amplitude << 1), morphology = no distinct single-peaked deviation at the very beginning or very end; time-frequency = lack of a concentrated localized low-frequency energy blob at the early/final time windows; heatmap color = absence of red marking in early/final low-frequency cells and sometimes slight blue elsewhere. Interpretation = absence of the label-0 defining feature reduces the model's support for class-0 and contributes indirectly to misclassification (marked as atypical relative to label-0).

Small early upward bump (occurrence ~t=12–28 in some samples, e.g., sample 24): manifestation = moderate, short-duration peak (amplitude around 0.2–0.4 on normalized baseline in some cases but sometimes larger relative to noise), morphology = narrow rise-and-fall; time-frequency = localized low-frequency energy but sometimes with some spread into adjacent frequencies (indicating slight jitter); heatmap color = often blue or mixed (negative SHAP) in examples here, especially when a large mid-plateau coexists. Interpretation = although a small early peak is the textbook feature of label-0, in these boundary samples this early peak is either weak or marked blue by the model (treated as atypical), so it fails to secure a class-0 decision.

Late small/narrow upward spike (occurrence ~t=120–125 in samples 38 and 45): manifestation = short-duration, relatively high amplitude spike (sharp morphology; amplitude sometimes close to plateau values but temporally narrow), time-frequency = energy appears both in the 0Hz row and also in slightly higher frequency rows (indicating a sharp transient); heatmap color = mixed — can be red at 0Hz low-frequency row (weak positive) but blue in adjacent higher-frequency rows or overall low magnitude compared to mid-plateau. Interpretation = when present but narrow/sharp, the model sometimes treats it as ambiguous or atypical (blue components) because its frequency spread looks different from the canonical smooth small peak of label-0. This leads to weak support for label-0 and helps misclassification.

Intermediate trough / local dip preceding a final peak (occurrence ~t=108–116 in sample 45): manifestation = a valley dropping to ~0.3–0.4 before a subsequent rise, morphology = pronounced dip then sharp recovery; time-frequency = shows low-frequency energy but with some intermediate-frequency content related to the change in slope; heatmap color = mixes blue (negative SHAP) at some frequencies and times. Interpretation = this valley+recovery pattern introduces atypical morphology relative to simple small-uppeak of label-0 and is treated as confusing/atypical by the model (contributes to misclassification).

Frequency spread / jitter signatures (various short-time high-frequency rows): manifestation = when a peak is jittery or very sharp, the STFT distributes energy into higher frequency rows; time-frequency = broader vertical band across multiple frequency rows rather than a concentrated 0Hz blob; heatmap color = adjacent low-frequency rows often show mixed (red near 0Hz, blue in higher rows) or net blue for some transients. Interpretation = the model favors smooth low-frequency peaks for label-0; when energy spreads upward (sharper transients), the model treats those components as atypical (blue) contributing to misclassification.

Baseline / quiet early stage (time ~0–52): baseline-level noise around 0.00–0.12 (plot shows many small jitters << 1.0), STFT: very low energy except tiny low-frequency components; SHAP heatmap: essentially neutral-to-slight positive/very weak red at a few low-frequency cells but no concentrated red blob. Interpretation: absence of a distinct isolated small early upward peak (i.e., the canonical label-0 feature) — this absence is an atypical feature for label-0 (heatmap lacks decisive red in early low-frequency cells). This missing early transient reduces support for class-0 in the model.

Dominant sustained mid-sequence plateau (time ~54–125, strongest ~60–120): abrupt rise around t≈50–55 from baseline to a high, then a long flat top at normalized values ≈2.0–2.12 sustained for many consecutive timesteps until ≈121–125, followed by a sharp fall back to baseline. STFT: very strong energy concentrated in the 0 Hz row and immediate adjacent low-frequency rows during this time window (narrow vertical spread, indicating a slowly varying DC-like plateau rather than high-frequency jitter). SHAP heatmap: strong red concentrated at the 0Hz (lowest) frequency row across ~54–108 (peak red intensity around ~75–95) and weaker red continuing until the plateau end. Interpretation: this is a typical feature for class-1 in the black-box model (strong positive SHAP). This large plateau is the dominant positive evidence that drives the model to predict class-1.

Sharp drop / final descent (time ~121–135): after the long plateau there is a rapid decline back to baseline between ≈121 and 135. STFT: energy decreases and some transient higher-frequency components appear briefly during the descent. SHAP heatmap: mixed/weak blue marks appear around the low-frequency rows in this late window (especially ≈121–135), indicating a small amount of atypical evidence for label-0 or negative evidence for label-0 in some frequency bins. Interpretation: the descent and associated transient are ambiguous-to-atypical relative to label-0 because they introduce higher-frequency content; however their magnitude is much smaller in SHAP than the strong red plateau evidence.

Absence of late small isolated upward spike (final window ~135–149): plot shows no narrow final positive spike near the very end; STFT: no localized concentrated energy blob at the very end; SHAP: no red marking in late tiny-window cells. Interpretation: this absence is again atypical for label-0 — the model lacks the canonical late small upward bump that would support class-0, so it does not counteract the plateau evidence.

Frequency concentration vs. spread: the plateau energy is tightly concentrated in the lowest-frequency row(s) (0Hz) with little vertical spread; STFT and heatmap show minor adjacent-row contributions but not the broad vertical band consistent with jittery/sharp transients. SHAP: the 0Hz row is strongly red while a few adjacent low-frequency rows are weaker red; higher-frequency rows are mostly neutral. Interpretation: the model treats a smooth, sustained DC-like plateau (low-frequency concentration) as prototypical for class-1, and this spectral signature is the key misclassification driver.
pattern: Sample 24 (true label = 0, model prediction = 1): Pattern = small early upward bump (t≈15–28) (narrow morphology, low-to-moderate amplitude, heatmap: blue/weak negative at several low-frequency cells) (interpreted by model as atypical for label-0) + large sustained mid-sequence plateau (t≈50–105) (high amplitude ∼2.0–2.2, long duration, concentrated energy at 0Hz and adjacent low frequencies, heatmap: strong red at low-frequency rows) (interpreted by model as typical for class-1). Net effect: the strong mid-plateau dominates the decision (positive SHAP) and the small early bump is either treated as ambiguous/atypical (blue), producing misclassification as class-1 (logits show class-1 highest).

Sample 37 (true label = 0, model prediction = 1): Pattern = absence of isolated early/final small upward peak (early and late windows show baseline jitter only; no distinct localized peak) (manifestation: lack of canonical label-0 transient; heatmap: no red localized early/final cells) + pronounced central plateau (t≈50–120) (sustained high amplitude near 2.0, concentrated low-frequency energy, heatmap: red strongly aligned with plateau). Net effect: missing the defining small-peak and the presence of an unambiguous mid-plateau lead the model to label as class-1 (logits heavily favor class-1).

Sample 38 (true label = 0, model prediction = 1): Pattern = dominant mid-sequence plateau (t≈45–98) (high amplitude, long plateau, low-frequency concentrated energy, heatmap: red at 0Hz) + a late narrow upward spike (t≈120–125) (sharp transient with some higher-frequency spread, heatmap: red at 0Hz but mixed/weak in adjacent rows or overall lower SHAP weight). Net effect: the plateau contributes strong positive evidence for class-1; the late spike does provide partial evidence for label-0 but its narrow/sharp shape spreads energy into higher frequencies and receives only limited positive SHAP support, so the model still predicts class-1 (logits favor class-1).

Sample 45 (true label = 0, model prediction = 1): Pattern = central plateau (t≈50–110) (sustained high amplitude, low-frequency energy, heatmap: red) + an intermediate valley/dip then a late sharp peak (valley t≈108–116 depth ~0.3–0.4 followed by sharp late spike t≈120–125) (manifestation = non-canonical morphology for label-0: valley+sharp recovery; time-frequency shows broader frequency content; heatmap: mixed with blue at some frequencies for the dip/spike). Net effect: the plateau strongly biases the classifier toward class-1; the dip+sharp late peak is considered atypical/ambiguous (blue or weak SHAP) and fails to correct the prediction to label-0, producing misclassification (model logits favor class-1).

Pattern A (true label = 0, predicted label = 1): Absence of canonical label-0 transient in early/late windows (time ~0–52 and ~135–149): no isolated small upward peak — heatmap: neutral/weak or absent red in those windows (interpreted as atypical for label-0) + Dominant long mid-sequence plateau (time ~54–125): abrupt rise then sustained flat top at amplitude ≈2.0–2.12; STFT: concentrated energy at 0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows; SHAP heatmap: strong red at 0Hz between ≈54–108 (strong positive contribution to class-1), weaker red through ≈108–121. Net effect: the strong red evidence from the sustained low-frequency plateau overwhelms the lack of early/late small peaks. Black-box logits: [class0=1.0835, class1=1.7082, class2=-0.6897] show class-1 favored; the plateau’s red SHAP signal is the decisive contributor that shifts prediction away from label-0.

Why this pattern is a classification boundary: The model has learned that small, smooth, localized low-frequency bumps near the sequence ends are characteristic of label-0. Here, those localized bumps are missing and replaced by a long, high-amplitude, low-frequency plateau that matches the class-1 spectral template (strong 0Hz energy). The combination (missing label-0 transient + strongly class-1-typical plateau) creates a boundary sample: if the plateau were shorter or if a clear early/late small peak existed, the model might prefer label-0; instead the plateau yields high positive SHAP mass for class-1 and produces the misclassification. The small transient signatures (descent and slight higher-frequency components at the end) are too weak and in some frequency bins are marked blue, so they do not counteract the plateau evidence.

feature: Baseline (early, time steps 0-44): type = baseline. Manifestation = low-amplitude, near-zero fluctuations around y=0 (value range approximately -0.05 to +0.15). Frequency mapping = energy concentrated at the 0 Hz row and the immediately adjacent low-frequency rows (very low spectral energy). Heatmap color = mostly neutral to very slight red/weak blue mix in scattered cells. Interpretation = these low-amplitude early baseline oscillations are mostly neutral for the target label (label 1 = Middle) and do not strongly drive classification; judged as typical/neutral features for label 1 (not the main cause of misclassification).

Large mid-sequence plateau/peak (time steps ~45-80): type = peak/plateau (morphological peak, extended). Manifestation = a sustained, large positive deviation from baseline: values around 2.4–2.6 (amplitude delta ~+2.4 to +2.6 above baseline). Morphology = abrupt rise beginning ~45–50, long stable high plateau from ~53 to ~78, then abrupt descent near ~80. Rate of change = steep positive slope entering plateau (within ~5–8 steps), very stable high amplitude across many time steps, then steep negative slope exiting plateau. Frequency mapping = strong energy concentrated in the 0 Hz row and immediate low-frequency rows in the STFT (dominant low-frequency / DC component due to long plateau), little high-frequency content inside the plateau itself. Heatmap color = mixed: this time region shows pronounced blue (negative SHAP) in the earlier part of the plateau (approx. 45–75 at 0Hz / low-freq rows) and localized red patches toward the tail/exit of the plateau (approx. 75–95 region at 0Hz/lowest-frequency rows). Interpretation = the sustained peak is atypical for label 1 (label 1 expects no peaks); the plateau's presence produces strong low-frequency energy that the model marks as atypical (blue) in its central portion. This plateau is a major atypical feature that pushes the model away from classifying the sample as label 1.

Abrupt downward transition / final trough-like return to baseline (time steps ~79-86): type = valley / downward transition (short-term trough relative to prior plateau). Manifestation = a fast negative excursion from ~2.5 down to ~0 within a few steps (large negative rate of change; amplitude change ~-2.4 over ~3–7 steps). Morphology = sharp drop and short tail to near-zero baseline; in time-domain it appears as a final downward trough-like event. Frequency mapping = localized concentrated energy in low-frequency row (0Hz) during the transition and some broader low-adjacent-frequency energy due to the abruptness; STFT shows energy across adjacent low-frequency rows during the descent. Heatmap color = strong red in the low-frequency rows for this final period (~80–95) indicating positive SHAP (features here are being treated as more supportive for the label being summarized). Interpretation = this sharp downward transition is interpreted by the model as a distinctive event; because label definitions state “small downward trough appears in the initial or final period” for label 2, the abrupt descent at the end resembles a Down-class signature. The heatmap shows the final descent region as red (typical for the summarized label), but given the heatmap is computed relative to label 1 context it indicates this local energy contributes toward the model's current internal scoring (mixed effect). Overall, the final trough-like event is a boundary-driving feature that can be (and appears to be) associated with other labels (particularly label 2), making it a likely cause of misclassification.

Late baseline jitter (time steps ~86-149): type = baseline / small jitter. Manifestation = after the steep drop back to baseline, small low-amplitude noise persists (values roughly 0.0–0.15 with occasional spikes). Frequency mapping = very low energy in STFT; small contributions in the 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows. Heatmap color = scattered faint red/blue cells, generally weak (near-neutral). Interpretation = these late small jitters are not decisive; they are minor and mostly neutral or weakly supportive/ambiguous in the heatmap, not primary causes of misclassification.
pattern: Sample 63 pattern (true label = label 1 - 'Middle'; model result = predicted label 2 'Down' with logits [-0.1473, 0.8577, 1.0607]): Combination = Early baseline (0–44) low-noise near-zero fluctuations (baseline) (neutral / weak red) + Large mid-sequence plateau/peak (45–80) (sustained amplitude ~2.4–2.6, abrupt rise then stable plateau then abrupt fall) (dominantly blue in heatmap during the plateau center → interpreted as atypical for label 1; pushes model away from label 1) + Abrupt downward transition / final trough at ~79–86 (fast negative change from ~2.5 to ~0, valley-like) (localized strong red in low-frequency heatmap cells around the transition in SHAP visualization and adjacent low-frequency support) + Late baseline jitter (86–149) (small amplitude near-zero fluctuations, neutral/weak). Heatmap & frequency mapping interpretation: the plateau produces a large low-frequency (0Hz and nearby) energy band seen in STFT; its mid-portion is marked blue in the SHAP heatmap (atypical for label 1) and hence contributes to lowering confidence in label 1. The abrupt descent at the end produces concentrated low-frequency energy at the transition and is associated with red SHAP cells in the immediate post-descent region; because label 2 is defined by a small downward trough at initial or final periods, that abrupt downward signature is strongly boundary-resembling and contributes to increasing the model's score for label 2. Why misclassification occurred: the combination of a large, atypical mid-sequence plateau (contradicting the 'no-peak' expectation of label 1) plus a sharp final downward transition (mimicking a Down-class trough in the final period) creates conflicting spectral/SHAP signals. The model's logits show label 2 slightly higher than label 1 (1.0607 vs. 0.8577), indicating that the atypical plateau (blue SHAP influence) together with distinctive downward-edge features have pushed the score marginally towards label 2. Conclusion: boundary-driving features are (1) extended mid-sequence plateau/large positive deviation (atypical for label 1; strong low-frequency energy; blue in SHAP) and (2) abrupt final downward transition/trough (valley-like in final period; spectral signature in low-frequency rows; interpreted by model as Down-like). These two combined create the boundary pattern that makes the sample prone to misclassification as label 2.

Detailed analysis and confirmation that the preliminary summary already covers the relevant misclassification-driving features and patterns for Sample 63 (predicted label 2, logits = [-0.1473, 0.8577, 1.0607]). Stepwise evidence and mapping: 

1) Time-domain morphology and quantitative description: The time series clearly splits into four practical stages: (a) Early baseline (time steps 0–44) — low-amplitude near-zero noise with values roughly between -0.05 and +0.15 and no sustained drift; (b) Abrupt rise and sustained plateau (approx. 45–80) — a steep climb starting ~45–53 reaching a stable high plateau around 2.4–2.6 where the amplitude delta relative to baseline is about +2.4–2.6; the plateau remains very stable (low intra-plateau volatility) from roughly 53 to ~78; (c) Fast downward transition / final trough-like return (approx. 79–86) — a rapid drop from ~2.5 back to ~0 across ~3–7 steps (large negative slope, amplitude change ~-2.4 in a short window); (d) Late baseline jitter (approx. 86–149) — low-amplitude near-zero noise with occasional small spikes, values ~0.0–0.15. These morphological stages and numeric ranges match the preliminary summary and are visible in the provided plot.

2) Time-frequency mapping (STFT) and energy distribution: The STFT shows dominant energy concentrated at the lowest frequency row (0 Hz) and immediately adjacent low-frequency rows during the plateau stage (highest energy region is between ~53 and ~78), consistent with a long DC-like plateau producing strong low-frequency content. During the descent (approx. 79–86) the STFT still shows concentrated low-frequency energy but with some spread to adjacent low-frequency rows because of the abruptness (transient content introduces slightly broader low-adjacent-frequency energy). Early and late baseline epochs show only weak low-frequency energy. This mapping is consistent with the preliminary description.

3) SHAP heatmap mapping to features and sign interpretation: The SHAP heatmap shows mainly blue shading across the central portion of the plateau in the 0 Hz and immediate low-frequency rows (i.e., the plateau center is marked as atypical relative to label 1). The immediate pre- and post-descent region and the descent window itself show red (positive SHAP) at the lowest-frequency row indicating that the abrupt final downward transition is treated by the model as a supporting/typical cue for the class being evaluated in the heatmap context. Early and late baselines are near-neutral with only faint mixed cells, consistent with the preliminary summary marking them as neutral/not decisive. This heatmap-color-to-feature mapping is explicitly stated in the preliminary summary and matches visual evidence.

4) Why misclassification occurs and boundary identification: The combination of (i) an extended, atypical mid-sequence plateau (blue in SHAP; strong low-frequency / DC energy; contradicts label 1’s 'no peaks' expectation) and (ii) a sharp final downward transition that spectrally and morphologically resembles the 'Down' signature in the final period (red in SHAP around the descent; concentrated low-frequency energy at the transition) creates a conflicting classification signal. The model’s logits (label 2 > label 1 by a small margin: 1.0607 vs. 0.8577) indicate the final trough-like event and the plateau’s atypicality combine to push the sample across the decision boundary toward label 2. The plateau reduces confidence in label 1 (blue influence) while the final descent increases label 2 support (red influence). Early and late baseline jitter are minor and not decisive.

Conclusion: The preliminary feature summary already enumerates and interprets all misclassification-driving events (early baseline neutral, large mid-sequence plateau marked blue/atypical, abrupt final downward trough marked red/typical-for-other-labels, late baseline jitter neutral). There are no omitted boundary-driving features in the preliminary summary; it captures the morphology, amplitude ranges, rate-of-change, STFT frequency mapping, heatmap coloration and the combined pattern that leads to misclassification. Therefore no additional feature entries are necessary beyond what is already provided in the preliminary summary.

feature: Baseline / Plateau (mid-sequence upward block) - occurrence: roughly time steps 50-100 (samples 121: ~50-95, 132: ~50-95, 143: ~45-105). Manifestation: sustained positive plateau / high constant amplitude (magnitude range approx +1.5 to +2.3), low volatility (flat-top shape with small jitter), slow transitions at edges (sharp rise around start of plateau and sharp drop at end). Time-frequency mapping: very strong energy concentrated in the lowest frequency row (0 Hz row) and immediately adjacent low-frequency rows (indicating a DC-like sustained deviation), STFT shows highest magnitudes in those time bins. Heatmap color: strongly red in the 0Hz row and adjacent low-frequency rows for the plateau region. Heatmap interpretation: the model treats this mid-sequence upward plateau as a typical feature for the predicted class (red = typical). This feature is a primary driver of the model's positive evidence for class 1 and is therefore implicated in misclassification.

Valley / Deep trough (early or late downward event) - occurrence: sample 121: early trough ~time 20-30 (center ~27); sample 132: late trough ~time 122-132 (center ~127); sample 143: late trough ~time 118-125 (center ~121-123). Manifestation: narrow, pronounced downward valley reaching large negative magnitudes (amplitude approx -1.2 to -2.4; sample 121 ~-2.0 at trough, sample 132 ~-1.3, sample 143 ~-2.3), smooth curvature (not highly oscillatory), localized in time (short duration relative to plateau). Time-frequency mapping: concentrated energy in low-frequency rows (0Hz and adjacent low-frequency bins) at corresponding times, STFT indicates strong low-frequency magnitude but localized. Heatmap color: predominantly blue (negative SHAP) in the low-frequency rows corresponding to the trough time windows; occasionally weak or neutral elsewhere. Heatmap interpretation: the model considers these large troughs atypical for the predicted class (blue = atypical), and in these samples the valley evidence is not strong enough (in the model's view) to overcome the mid-sequence plateau evidence favoring class 1. Thus the trough is a critical boundary feature whose atypical marking contributes to classification confusion and misclassification when combined with competing features.

Small baseline jitter / noise (throughout early and late background) - occurrence: present across entire sequence but most visible in pre/post plateau regions (~0-45 and ~105-150). Manifestation: small amplitude fluctuations around y=0, magnitude roughly between -0.1 and +0.1, irregular low-amplitude jitter. Time-frequency mapping: low-energy spread across a few low-to-intermediate frequency components (not concentrated). Heatmap color: near-neutral to weak red/blue mixture (mostly white / faint colors), indicating low contribution or ambiguous effect. Heatmap interpretation: these jitter features are generally ambiguous/neutral and are not primary drivers of the misclassification; they produce minimal SHAP magnitude and mixed colors.

Edge transition slopes (rise and fall at plateau boundaries) - occurrence: transitions at plateau start (~time 45-55) and plateau end (~time 95-105) in all samples. Manifestation: relatively steep upward and downward slopes (sharp change over a small number of time steps), slope magnitude moderate (change of ~1.5-2 units over ~5-10 time steps), shape is sharp but not oscillatory. Time-frequency mapping: energy appears mainly in low-frequency rows but with slightly more spread into the adjacent frequency bins than the plateau (indicating some transient frequency content). Heatmap color: predominantly red at the plateau start and end in 0Hz and the immediate adjacent rows (sometimes with mixed small blue in adjacent bins), indicating the model treats these transitional edges largely as evidence supporting the plateau class. Heatmap interpretation: these edges strengthen the model's confidence in the plateau feature and thus indirectly contribute to misclassification.

Intermediate low-level positive energy preceding plateau (weak pre-plateau increase) - occurrence: small positive buildup just before plateau in some samples (e.g., sample 132 shows slight rise ~time 45). Manifestation: small amplitude increase (~0.1-0.3) lasting a few time steps. Time-frequency mapping: faint low-frequency energy. Heatmap color: faint red in low-frequency rows or neutral. Heatmap interpretation: weakly typical/ambiguous; these features marginally support the plateau interpretation but are minor contributors.
pattern: Sample 121 (True label: 2 (Down) ; Model predicted: 1). Pattern composition: Early deep valley (valley at time ~20-30, amplitude approx -2.0) (blue in heatmap at 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows → interpreted as atypical by model) + Mid-sequence large positive plateau (time ~50-95, amplitude approx +1.8-1.95, low volatility) (strong red in 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows → interpreted as typical for predicted class) + Stable low-amplitude jitter in pre/post regions (neutral/faint) (heatmap near-neutral). Heatmap mapping: the model's SHAP heatmap shows strong negative contributions (blue) located at the early trough low-frequency bins but dominant positive contributions (red) across the plateau low-frequency bins. Why misclassified: although the sample contains the label-2-defining trough, the model gives much stronger positive evidence to the mid-sequence plateau (red, large magnitude at low frequencies), and the atypical marking of the trough is not sufficient to flip the decision. Logits: [-1.078, 1.670, 1.241] show class 1 highest, indicating plateau evidence overwhelms trough evidence.

Sample 132 (True label: 2 (Down) ; Model predicted: 1). Pattern composition: Mid-sequence sustained plateau (time ~50-95, amplitude approx +2.0-2.2, pronounced, low-frequency concentrated energy) (strong red in 0Hz and adjacent low-frequency rows → typical for predicted class) + Late localized trough (time ~122-132, amplitude approx -1.2 to -1.4) (blue in low-frequency rows in heatmap → atypical) + Minor pre-plateau small rise (weak red/neutral). Heatmap mapping: bright red low-frequency region during plateau dominates; blue low-frequency region at late trough is visible but less influential. Why misclassified: the model prioritizes the dominant mid-sequence plateau as evidence for class 1; the late trough is considered atypical and not decisive. Logits: [-0.798, 1.904, 1.261] indicate strong preference for class 1 (largest logit), consistent with red plateau influence.

Sample 143 (True label: 2 (Down) ; Model predicted: 1). Pattern composition: Mid-sequence plateau (time ~45-105, amplitude approx +1.5-1.7, sustained) (red in low-frequency 0Hz row and adjacent rows → typical) + Late deep trough (time ~118-125, amplitude approx -2.3) (blue in low-frequency rows in heatmap → atypical) + Minor baseline jitter elsewhere (neutral). Heatmap mapping: model SHAP shows a clear red band across plateau low-frequency bins and a blue band at the trough low-frequency bins; the plateau red region is stronger. Why misclassified: despite a deep late trough characteristic of label 2, the model's decision is dominated by the mid-sequence upward plateau which it regards as typical for the predicted class (class 1). Logits: [-0.997, 1.466, 1.098] with class 1 largest, indicating plateau influence overcame trough evidence.

Reflection on boundary features and misclassification mechanism (combined across samples): In all three samples the recurring boundary pattern is 'strong mid-sequence sustained positive plateau (low-frequency concentrated energy and red in heatmap) + localized deep trough (the down-feature expected for label 2) marked as blue in heatmap'. The model assigns greater positive weight to the plateau (red, typical for predicted class 1), while the true label's defining trough is judged atypical (blue) or insufficient, producing misclassification. The logits across samples consistently show class 1 with the highest logit, confirming that the plateau feature dominates model decision-making. Therefore, the combination of a dominant, sustained upward plateau and a localized trough is a prototypical boundary pattern that causes the model to prefer the non-true label.
